newsitem.title: UK: It's back to real carrots, according to study.
newsitem.headline: It's back to real carrots, according to study.

text.p: Another study has found no health benefit from taking vitamin supplements, adding to evidence that people cannot escape eating real vegetables to protect themselves from cancer and heart disease.
The study, in the Lancet medical journal, found that vitamin A and E supplements did not protect middle-aged male smokers from having a second heart attack.

Janne Rapola of the National Public Health Institute in Helsinki and colleagues at the U.S. National Cancer Institute studied more than 1,800 men as part of the Alpha-tocopherol Beta-carotene Cancer Prevention study (ABCPS).
All were smokers over the age of 50 who had suffered one heart attack.
They were given either a combination of A or E supplements, or a placebo pill containing nothing.
"There were no significant differences in the number of major coronary events between any supplementation group and the placebo group," Rapola's group wrote.
"In fact, the risk of fatal coronary heart disease increased in the groups that received either beta-carotene or the combination of alpha-tocopherol and beta-carotene," they added.
"We do not recommend the use of alpha-tocopherol (which the body turns into vitamin E) or beta-carotene (which becomes a form of vitamin A) supplements in this group of patients."
A 1996 study known as the Cambridge Heart Antioxidant Study (CHAOS) found that supplements slightly decreased the risk of heart attack but not overall coronary deaths in patients with heart disease.
A U.S. study the same year found beta-carotene seemed to help heart disease at first but in fact slightly increased the risk of death.

"This report is important because it adds substantially to the scant body of clinical trial data about treatment of ischaemic heart disease with vitamin E and beta-carotene," Nigel Stephens, a cardiologist at Northwick Park Hospital near London, said in a commentary.
Findings were contradictory and of course more research was needed, he added.

"Meanwhile there continues to be good reason to believe that a high dose of vitamin E may prevent myocardial infarction (heart attack) in patients with coronary atherosclerosis, but there is no further mileage in the clinical use of beta-carotene."

Rapola's group said it was not clear how supplements might increase the risk of death. It could be their anti-oxidant activity affected a process known as preconditioning, which the body uses to protect itself against heart blockages and the resulting lack of oxygen.
Or it could be beta-carotene, which is easily absorbed into the plaque that coats blood vessel walls in atherosclerosis, somehow helps the plaque rupture and form a clot more easily.
Meanwhile, men who have suffered heart attacks should not take supplements, they said.
Other studies have found clear evidence that eating lots of fruit and vegetables protects against both cancer and heart disease.
